T rau experiments of Boyle have proved beyond doubt that air is eminently elastic and therefore spreads and expands immensely when relieved from the pressure of the atmosphere. But it is not so clear to what cause the elastic force of the air is due. I shall, how- ever, state briefly the result of my reflections on this recondite subject.

In the first place, then, I take it for granted that the air contains certain particles termed by us elsewhere nitro-aerial which are absolutely indispensable for the productiori of fire, and that these in the burning of flame are drawn from the air and removed, so that the latter when deprived of these particles ceases to be fit for supporting fire, as has been shown above.

It must also be admitted that the clastic force ol the air is due to the same aerial particles as those by which flame is supported-an inference which we deduce from the fact that air deprived of these nitro- ae'rial particles loses clastic force, as will be established by what follows.
